abstracts.cdata!:
Based on the achievement of specific
            objectives specified in the Staff Appraisal Report,
            availability of plans for sustainability, and dissemination
            and improved project management capacity, the project has
            been rated satisfactory, but with some reservations on
            effectiveness and efficiency for a better investment in the
            future. Project sustainability is uncertain. Overall
            performances by the World Bank and the Borrower were
            satisfactory. Key lessons for the Bank included the
            following: school clusters have been able to provide a
            mechanism for teachers to mutually support each other in
            quality improvement efforts. Decentralized and participatory
            in-service training programs are more effective and
            efficient than centralized, traditional lecture mode.
            Participation techniques can enhance community ownership to
            the schools. There is a need for close cooperation between
            the ministries of education and culture, and home affairs in
            managing quality improvement. Training for the head teachers
            in the use of grants will influence the success of the
            intervention. Decentralizing authority to agencies and the
            community at lower levels to select scholarship and grants
            recipients can enhance ownership by both government and
            community and help assure transparency. Lessons for the
            government included the following: Training should be based
            on teacher needs. Good head teachers are essential in
            developing good schools. Parents should be involved in
            student learning processes.
